item.title: Jessica add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Angry people are not always wise." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "A woman, especially if she have the misfortune of knowing anything, should conceal it as well as she can." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Silly things do cease to be silly if they are done by sensible people in an impudent way." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Jane Austen
item.description: "Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how." -- Jane Austen

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Sylvia Plath
item.description: "If neurotic is wanting two mutually exclusive things at one and the same time, then I'm neurotic as hell. I'll be flying back and forth between one mutually exclusive thing and another for the rest of my days." -- Sylvia Plath

item.title: Jessica add a quote by sylvia plath
item.description: "Perhaps when we find ourselves wanting everything, it is because we are dangerously close to wanting nothing." -- sylvia plath

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Anne Sexton
item.description: "As for me, I am a watercolor. I wash off." -- Anne Sexton

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "You speak an infinite deal of nothing." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by Henry van Dyke
item.description: "Time is Too Slow for those who Wait, Too Swift for those who Fear, Too Long for those who Grieve, Too Short for those who Rejoice; But for those who Love, Time is not." -- Henry van Dyke

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespear
item.description: "There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so." -- William Shakespear

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "To be, or not to be: that is the question: Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them? To die: to sleep; No more; and by a sleep to say we end The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to, 'tis a consummation Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep; To sleep: perchance to dream: ay, there's the rub; For in that sleep of death what dreams may come When we have shuffled off this mortal coil, Must give us pause: there's the respect That makes calamity of so long life; For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely, The pangs of despised love, the law's delay, The insolence of office and the spurns That patient merit of the unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin? who would fardels bear, To grunt and sweat under a weary life, But that the dread of something after death, The undiscover'd country from whose bourn No traveller returns, puzzles the will And makes us rather bear those ills we have Than fly to others that we know not of? Thus conscience does make cowards of us all; And thus the native hue of resolution Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, And enterprises of great pith and moment With this regard their currents turn awry, And lose the name of action.--Soft you now! The fair Ophelia! Nymph, in thy orisons Be all my sins remember'd!" -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day? Thou art more lovely and more temperate: Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May, And summer's lease hath all too short a date: Sometimes too hot the eye of heaven shines, And too often is his gold complexion dimm'd: And every fair from fair sometimes declines, By chance or natures changing course untrimm'd; By thy eternal summer shall not fade, Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest; Nor shall Death brag thou wander'st in his shade, When in eternal lines to time thou growest: So long as men can breathe or eyes can see, So long lives this and this gives life to thee." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Dispute not with her: she is lunatic." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "To die, to sleep - To sleep, perchance to dream - ay, there's the rub, For in this sleep of death what dreams may come..." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Conscience doth make cowards of us all." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "[Thine] face is not worth sunburning." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "I am not bound to please thee with my answer." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "In time we hate that which we often fear." -- William Shakespeare

item.title: Jessica add a quote by William Shakespeare
item.description: "Exit, pursued by a bear." -- William Shakespeare
